posts.name: Evan B
posts.cooked:
I’ve been creating technical drawings to machine parts for a summer project, but the drawings don’t facilitate easy communication with the machinist. I thought learning GD&T would help, yet it appears quite complex and challenging to grasp. Additionally, our team doesn’t have access to CNC machining capabilities that rely on detailed technical drawings.  

Do other teams utilize GD&T? Should I begin using GD&T? If yes, what is the most effective way to learn it?

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: I do not represent other teams, but we generally utilize Onshape drawings as an integrated tool. This simplifies the CAD process for anyone creating drawings.

posts.name: paulonis
posts.cooked: The text is: we typically use Onshape drawings as its integrated GD&T system. GD&T is a system for communicating engineering tolerances between design and manufacturing. Onshape drawings have the geometric tolerances and datums needed for GD&T but the designer must know how to use those tools. I don’t know how many teams employ the rigor of GD&T. If a team uses a sponsor for machining and expects GD&T tolerancing from them, it would be beneficial for that team to learn and use GD&T.

posts.name: s-neff
posts.cooked:
GD&T will not result in easier communication.

It requires understanding what your machinist needs from your drawings to create precise parts. Ask open-ended questions and explain that this is your first project, seeking their guidance to improve your drawing set. They likely know what’s missing better than others online.

GD&T is a highly specific system for high-precision engineering data communication. Unless your machinist voluntarily adopts it, it won’t simplify your design communication.

Effective communication of your design demands collaboration with another human, who must fully understand the component and verify its correctness. This involves clearly describing how to manufacture it.

In most cases, modern machine shops rely on CAD files primarily, with paper drawings only for critical quality checks. Thus, only interface dimensions and specific bore callouts are needed on the paper.

For manual manufacturing, creating a comprehensive paper drawing set requires clear communication of all necessary dimensions, typically using an ordinate system so the machinist can work from a single reference point. If unclear, collaboration with your machinist to understand and define the problem is essential.

posts.name: Skuke (aka: Payton)
posts.cooked:
If I understand correctly, you’re having parts made by your team in your school workspace rather than parts sent to an outside machine shop. I wouldn’t suggest you use GD&T because it’s too time-consuming for both you and the manufacturing students. You could include some common symbols in your drawings if time permits, but don’t expect much progress. The students struggle with keeping things within simple tolerances, making additional constraints difficult.

Instead, focus on becoming very proficient at dimensioning your drawings. Make sure dimensions are complete, clear, and minimize the need for complex calculations. Use appropriate tolerances, notes, and avoid ambiguity.

I used to be skilled in GD&T but haven’t used it actively in 25 years, so I’ve forgotten a lot. However, as an internal machinist, I found it more useful to communicate important details on drawings to engineers or designers. This allowed me to effectively meet their needs.

Additionally, I want to ensure you can inspect parts using GD&T to confirm they meet specifications. Without this, how can I verify the value of what I’m paying for? Tight tolerances or over/tight ones add costs through extra time, effort, or materials.

GD&T is valuable for engineers and designers, but it’s not necessary during your FIRST Robotics Competition experience. Take your time learning it now, as you probably won’t need it later.

Coincidentally, I came across a link to an introduction on GD&T, but I’m not endorsing it. There are plenty of other resources available.

For those ready, GD&T basics include True Position, concentricity, parallelism, perpendicularity, circularity, straightness, flatness, and angularity. Master these fundamentals before diving deeper into GD&T. Always prioritize learning how to create clear and effective drawings first.

link_counts.title: Introduction to Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing | Fictiv

posts.name: Adam Fleming
posts.cooked: True Position, especially on holes, is the most useful for an FRC team. When learning GD&T, the class focused on creating drawings to communicate inspection methods rather than production instructions. However, for FRC, it may be better to communicate production plans depending on team experience. My drawings often struggle to clearly instruct machinists, typically due to unclear dimensions or orientation issues.

posts.name: Evan B
posts.cooked:
The text is:  
The team is inexperienced, and despite having created many drawings with simple dimensioning rules over two build seasons, they struggle to get the machinist to understand their designs. This is partly due to limited meeting time, which forces the user to frequently monitor the machinist's work, often while they're occupied with other tasks. A mentor provides valuable feedback by questioning the user's drawings, though this doesn't bother the user much since the mentor is correct and the user's drawings are deemed "not good enough." Additionally, the lack of time prevents the user from having students teach them how to create effective drawings. The user's question is about transitioning from a beginner level to effectively communicating design intent through drawings without extensive face-to-face explanations. The user uses OnShape.

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked:
Face to face communication is not a waste of time. Let me clarify that.  
I've marked up and sent back drawings on my team for missing dimensions.  

When communicating the intent of something depicted in a drawing, it's essential to ensure clear communication. However, effective communication becomes simpler when both parties share common understanding. This isn't a CAD-related issue.  

In my opinion, the first step is to learn how to machine using the appropriate tools. Creating parts from drawings, including ones you've created, while marking them up with missing dimensions or notes will enhance your understanding. Once you grasp what's missing in the drawings you're sending for machining, incorporating those details will streamline the process.

posts.name: Skuke (aka: Payton)
posts.cooked:
I completely agree with the comments from EricH. He offers excellent advice. Good communication, including active listening, is crucial in most aspects of life. Another important point is that your school-based machinists may be just as inexperienced as you. While they are in a learning environment, even if they provide precise drawings, their peers from more established organizations like major companies or startups might still face challenges.  

In my extensive experience over 30 years, I frequently encountered questions about dimensions or features during machining projects. These drawings often come from recognizable, high-profile industries such as medical, technology, defense, aerospace, and even smaller startups or family-owned businesses. Don’t take it personally. Recognizing areas for improvement and striving to address them is a positive step toward growth.

posts.name: Skuke (aka: Payton)
posts.cooked:
How should I move from my beginner level to improve my ability to effectively communicate my intent regarding creating a drawing without spending time explaining the entire process face to face? 

1. Ask the machinist additional questions about what information they need beyond what I’ve already provided. Treat these requests as constructive feedback.  
2. Recognize that completing a part efficiently the first time is valuable and not time-wasting.  
3. Engage in a conversation with the machinist to explain the complexities of my drawing.  

For example, “Please ensure the hole in this block aligns with the other hole so the shaft can slide smoothly between them” (get the shaft if possible).  
Note: The machinist may not need to know the holes are for lateral intake on the bot.

posts.name: Adam Fleming
posts.cooked: I still can’t perfect the art of getting the machinist to understand what I want to be made. The best way to understand how to communicate how you want a part to look is to learn how to make the part. Work with the machinist as they make the parts, and make some parts yourself. One of the most useful classes I had in high school (almost a decade and a half ago…) was my intro to machine tools class. I only received a C on the final project, but that class taught the basics of what dimensions and details are needed to make a part.

posts.name: Patrick
posts.cooked:
Here’s what I would check first on a drawing:

- Is the part fully defined? Ensure the drawing can only be interpreted one way.
- Is there a consistent datum? Select a corner, a point where three faces meet; all locations should be dimensioned from these faces unless a strong reason exists otherwise.
- If a measurement is significantly more important than others, dimension it and label it as critical or assign it a tolerance.

Use reasonable standard tolerances. If a standard tolerance exists in the title block, ensure both parties share expectations. Avoid ambiguous tolerances, such as those used by the user’s former employer, which led to specification mismatches due to suppliers ignoring them. Always document deviations accurately.

posts.name: Andrew Torrance
posts.cooked:
Agreed with others’ comments.

On 254, we do drawings with dimensions and use the default tolerance block, typically 0.XXX = +/- 0.005".

For shaft facing:
- We adjust the nominal length of the model to be +0.01" for snap rings or -0.01" for shoulders bearing journals, ensuring compatibility with bearings in plates within +/- 0.005" machining tolerance.

For router bearing press fits:
- We usually offset the CAM undersize and chase it with a reamer in a drill press.

For shaft turning diameter for bearing journals:
- We use 1 bearing size available at the lathe as a fit check to achieve a nice slip fit.

To the question of “do I need to know this for my future career as a Mechanical Engineer”:
I work for J&J on surgical robots and we use GD&T extensively. It helps communicate design intent to the machine shop and ensures parts/tolerance stackups fit as intended. Interns at J&J (or in general in the industry) are not expected to have learned GD&T, and nearly all haven’t fully mastered it. It’s something taught on the job with guidance and peer review.

posts.name: Stanford Orfila
posts.cooked:
Seconded on the idea that interns aren’t expected to have learned GD&T. My understanding of it—which is still just scratching the surface—is gained through hands-on experience, primarily from engineers who also had to learn it on the job.  

I was actually supposed to have been exposed to it a little bit in one of my classes, but unfortunately, that class was taught by someone who is, quite frankly, one of the worst human beings I’ve ever encountered, so that never happened.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Use code FRC2710 for 5% off Fabworks.com

posts.name: Cory
posts.cooked:
The text is extremely importantily - do not output anything but the cleaned version (no introduction, no other little explanation), just the cleaned paragraph. The text is: The text is:
Suke:

If you want to use GD&T, keep it simple and use just the basics: True Position, concentricity, parallelism, perpendicularity, circularity, straightness, flatness and angularity. That should cover most(?) things that you would likely design. But as I already mentioned, first learn to dimension your drawing well.

I don’t know that I would even agree these are simple or the basics.

  • Position is virtually unmeasurable for a FRC team (also, pedantic, but “true position” is a misnomer - that is the theoretically perfect position of the feature - “position” is the GD&T tolerance that dictates the zone the feature’s axis must reside inside of)
  • Concentricity is a bad callout that doesn’t mean what people think it means (and it consequently has been removed from Y14.5 as of 2018).
  • Circularity is nearly useless as it only controls form and not orientation. Cylindricity is useful, but hard to measure
  • Straightness is maybe useful and stands a chance of being measurable by a FRC team, but still, probably not necessary as we have a tendency to just force less stiff things into alignment by more stiff things.
  • Flatness is actually reasonably measurable, but again probably doesn’t matter much for FRC purposes
  • Angularity is a nearly useless callout and can’t easily be measured by FRC teams

If you’re going to be a ME, eventually you’ll want a strong working knowledge of GD&T. If you exit college knowing what all the symbols are used for and what they control, you’re way ahead of the curve, even if you don’t know exactly how to apply them or what tolerances/datum reference frames would be appropriate.

GD&T is of zero use in FRC though.

posts.name: Skuke (aka: Payton)
posts.cooked: I don’t know if these are simple or the basics, but position in FIRST Robotics Competition (FRC) teams is nearly impossible to measure accurately. Additionally, concentricity was removed from the Y14.5 standard in 2018. When I took GD&T training years ago, true position was replaced with just position. As for basic GD&T symbols, I’d start with the ones related to position and straightness, then move on to parallelism and perpendicularity.
